close_symbols: OS_FdSet (struct definition, including object_ids member and its element type)
explanation:
Why each symbol is required for analyzing the MISRA rule (Controlling expressions shall not be invariant):

- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex
  - The controlling expression in the function is "return_code == OS_SUCCESS" where return_code is assigned from this function. To determine whether the if-expression can be invariant you must know the possible return values and behavior (e.g. whether it can return varying results for different objid inputs or is effectively a constant).

- OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_ObjectIdToSerialNumber_Impl, OS_GetMaxForObjectType
  - These symbols appear as implementation dependencies of OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex (per the call graph). To determine if OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex can produce a non-varying/result-constant value you may need the logic/data these helpers provide (type extraction, serial number computation, max-per-type checks).

- OS_SUCCESS
  - The constant compared against return_code in the controlling expression. Its numeric value and semantics are required to decide whether return_code can equal this constant or is always different (i.e. whether the comparison is invariant).

- OS_CHECK_POINTER
  - This macro is invoked at the top of the function and may expand to additional conditionals or an early return. Its expansion can introduce other controlling expressions and can affect whether the subsequent if-expression is reachable or invariant. You must inspect its definition to account for any conditionals it contains.

- OS_printf
  - OS_printf may be invoked by OS_CHECK_POINTER or by the implementations above (or by stubs). Knowing whether these helper routines perform side-effects or conditional logging is useful when examining macro expansions and whether any conditional expression inside them is invariant.

- OS_FdSet (struct definition, including object_ids member and its element type)
  - Although not directly part of the if controlling expression, the macro/assignment Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] |= 1 << (local_id & 0x7) uses object_ids; the type (e.g. uint8_t[]) and bounds/size are needed to ensure the code behaves as expected and that no constant-folding or undefined behavior would make the prior condition redundant/invariant in practice.

- osal_index_t (typedef) and osal_id_t (typedef)
  - The exact types affect the semantics of the shifts, masks and index computations, and may influence whether local_id is constrained to a narrow range (which could make expressions effectively constant). Also useful for reasoning about whether OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex can only return a fixed index or failure code.

In short, to decide whether the controlling expression "return_code == OS_SUCCESS" is invariant you need the full definition/semantics of OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex (and its helpers), the value of OS_SUCCESS, and the definitions of any macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER) invoked before the if. The listed type and struct definitions are included because they can constrain values or contribute conditionals that affect invariance.
